The transfer map and a result of Segal's

Mar 6, 2020

Suppose is a fiber bundle. The Becker-Gottlieb transfer produces a stable map , which one might think of as a map (where ). Segal used this map to show that there is a splitting of the canonical map . This is a strong version of the splitting principle, because may be regarded as the moduli of formal sums of line bundles. I’d like to understand this splitting from a moduli-theoretic point of view.

We need to create a map , so we should begin by understanding precisely the moduli problems classified by both. Since classifies virtual vector bundles, one can define (see Section 6.2 here) a category whose objects are pairs of finite-dimensional vector spaces (thought of as formal differences ), and whose morphisms are injective linear transformations and along with a subspace such that the maps and are isomorphisms. This can be given the structure of a topological category, and we’ll abusively identify it with its nerve. Then there is an equivalence .

So what is from this point of view? First note that is the geometric realization of , where the objects are one-dimensional complex vector spaces and the morphisms are isomorphisms. One can form the free symmetric monoidal -category , and the group completion of its geometric realization is .

This group completion process might be a little uncomfortable, so perhaps what we should try to do is construct a functor ; then, the group completion of its geometric realization would be . What would this functor be?

Consider the topological category consisting of -dimensional vector spaces and isomorphisms. Then there is a map sending a -tuple of lines to their direct sum. There is a functor , and so by left Kan extending along , we obtain a functor . This should be thought of as the functor

Since , we get the desired map by sticking together all of these functors.

Actually, I think the same argument produces a stable splitting of the map , where the moduli-theoretic interpretation of these spaces is via Grassmannians of planes in . The observation now is that this construction should work motivically, and so leads to a splitting of as .

There’s also a cute proof of the complex Adams conjecture this way. Recall that this states that if is a topological generator of , then the composite of (invert ) with the J-homomorphism is null. Since splits off , it suffices to prove that the Adams conjecture is true for line bundles — but there it is obvious! A similar thing works motivically.

I think a very interesting question (possibly with an answer obvious to others) is the following. The Segal splitting of off gives the Snaith theorem: the Bott element lands in the component of , and from this we can obtain a map . The Snaith theorem states that this is an equivalence (of -rings!), and this is a consequence of the fact that the fiber of the map is -torsion.

There’s another Snaith theorem, stating that . So we can ask whether splits off . I do not know how to answer this. (It is true rationally.) Perhaps, though, the interpretation of via colliding points in up to cobordism (see the introduction here for the jazzed up motivic version) can be coupled with a Kan extension/transfer-esque construction? I don’t know.
